lesson.name: Lesson 2.5: Solving Systems by Elimination, Part 3

page.title: 2.5.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will explore the idea that you can multiply one or both equations in the system by a factor to make it possible to eliminate a variable. In addition, you will learn whenever you multiply equations in a system by a factor, add or subtract the equations, or otherwise manipulate the equations, you are essentially creating an equivalent system that will help you get closer to finding the solution of the original system.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain how multiplying equations by a factor can help solve systems of linear equations.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  •     2.5.1: Multiplying Equations by a Number
  •     2.5.2: Writing a New System to Solve a Given System
  •     2.5.2: Self Check
  •     2.5.3: Finding Solutions to Unordered Sets of Equivalent Systems
  •     2.5.3: Self Check
  •     2.5.4: Building Equivalent Systems

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.5.5: Practice
  • 2.5.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 2.5.1: Multiplying Equations by a Number
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Consider two equations in a system:

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 4x+ y=1\\ x+2y=9 \end{array}\right. \) Equation A
Equation B
1. Use graphing technology to graph the equations. Then, identify the coordinates of the solution.


Enter your answer here:

1. \( (-1,5) \)



2. Write a few equations that are equivalent to equation A by multiplying both sides by the same number, for example, 2, -5, or \( \frac{1}{2} \) . Let’s call the resulting equations A1, A2, and A3.  

Enter your answer here:

2. Answers:

  • A1: \( 8x+2y=2 \)
  • A2: \( -20x-5y=-5 \)
  • A3: \( 2x+ \frac{1}{2} y= \frac{1}{2} \)


3. Graph the equations you generated. Make a couple of observations about the graphs.

Enter your answer here:

3. No new graphs appeared. The graphs of the equivalent equations are identical to that of Equation A. The graphs all intersect the graph of Equation B at (1, -5).

page.title: 2.5.2: Writing a New System to Solve a Given System
page.contents:
Activity

Here is a system you solved by graphing earlier.

\( \begin {cases}\begin {align} 4x + \hspace{2.2mm} y &= \hspace {2mm}1 &\quad&\text{Equation A}\\ x + 2y &= \hspace {2mm} 9&\quad&\text{Equation B} \end{align} \end{cases} \)

To start solving the system, Elena wrote:

\( \begin {align} 4x + \hspace{2.2mm} y &= \hspace {2mm}1\\ 4x + 8y &= 36 \end{align} \)

And then she wrote:

\( \begin {align} 4x + \hspace{2.2mm} y &= \hspace {3mm}1\\ 4x + 8y &= \hspace{1mm}36 \hspace{1.5mm}- \\ \overline {\hspace{8mm}\text-7y} &\overline{\hspace{1mm}=\text-35 \hspace{5mm}}\end{align} \)

1. What were Elena's first two moves? What might be possible reasons for those moves?

Enter your answer here:

1. First, she multiplied each side of the second equation by 4, which produces an equivalent equation with 4x in it. Next, she subtracted the new equation from the first equation. Doing that creates another equation where the variable x is eliminated, leaving only one variable and making it possible to solve for \( y \).


2. Complete the solving process algebraically. Show that the solution is indeed \( x = -1 \), \( y = 5 \).

Enter your answer here:

2. \( -7y=-35 \) can be rewritten as \( y=5 \). Substituting 5 for \( y \) in the first equation, we have \( 4x+5=1 \) or \( 4x=-4 \), which means \( x=-1 \).

Video: Writing a New System to Solve a Given System

Watch the following video to learn more about writing a new system of equations to solve a situation of constraints.

page.title: 2.5.2: Self Check
page.contents:
Solve the system of equations using elimination.

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}\;6x\;–\;5y\;=\;–34\\2x\;+\;6y\;=\;4\end{array}\right.\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair makes only the second equation true. Did you multiply the second equation by 3? The answer is (–4, 2).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair makes only the second equation true. Did you multiply the second equation by 3? The answer is (–4, 2).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The ordered pair makes both equations true.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair doesn’t make either equation true. Did you multiply the second equation by 3? The answer is (–4, 2).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure

page.title: 2.5.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving a System of Equations by Elimination Using Multiplication 

Let’s look at an example where we need to multiply both equations by constants in order to make the coefficients of one variable opposites.

Solve the system by elimination: \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}\;4x-3y=9\\7x+2y=-6\end{array}\right.\)

Solution:

In this example, we cannot multiply just one equation by any constant to get opposite coefficients. So we will strategically multiply both equations by different constants to get the opposites.

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}\;4x-3y=9\\7x+2y=-6\end{array}\right.\)
Both equations are in standard form.
To get opposite coefficients of y, we will
multiply the first equation by 2 and the
second equation by 3.		 \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}2(4x-3y)=2(9)\\\;3(7x+2y)=3(-6)\end{array}\right.\)
Simplify. \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}8x-6y=18\\\;21+y=-18\end{array}\right.\)
Add the two equations to eliminate y. \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}8x-6y=18\\\;21x+6y=-18\end{array}\right.\\29x\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;=0\\\)
Solve for x. \(x=0\)
\(7x+2y=-6\)
Substitute  𝑥=0 x = 0 into one of the original equations. \(7\cdot0+8y-6\)
Solve for y. \(2y=-6\\y=-3\)
Write the solution as an ordered pair. The ordered pair is (0,-3)

Check that the ordered pair is a solution to
both original equations.


\(4x-3y=9\\4(0)-3(-3)\overset?{=9}\\9=9✔\;\;\) 

 \(7x+2y=-6\\7(0)+2(-3)\overset?{=-6}\\-6=-6✔\)

The solution is  (0,-3)

Try It: Solving a System of Equations by Elimination Using Multiplication

Solve the following system of equations using elimination:

\[\left\{\begin{array}{l}7x+8y=4\\3x-5y=27\end{array}\right.\]

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve the system by elimination:


Write both equations in standard form. If any coefficients are fractions, clear them.

        \(7x + 8y = 4\)

         \(3x – 5y = 27\)

Check to see if the coefficients of one variable are opposites or equivalent. To get opposite coefficients of y, we will need to multiply the first equation by 5 and the second equation by 8.

         \(5(7x + 8y) = 5(4)\)

         \(8(3x – 5y) = 8(27)\)

Simplify.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}35x\;+\;40y\;&=&\;20\\24x\;–\;40y\;&=&\;216\\&&\end{array}\)

Add the equations to eliminate one variable.

\(\begin{array}{r}35x\;+\;40y\;=\;20\\24x\;–\;40y\;=\;216\\\overline{59x\;=\;236}\\\end{array}\)

Solve for the remaining variable.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}59x\;&=&\;236\\x\;&=&\;4\\&&\end{array}\)

Substitute the solution into one of the original equations. Then solve for the other variable.

      \(\begin{array}{rcl}7x+8y&=&4\\7(4)+8y&=&4\\28+8y&=&4\\8y&=&–24\\y&=&–3\\&&\end{array}\)

Write the solution as an ordered pair.

    (4, –3)

Check that the ordered pair is a solution to both original equations.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}\;7x\;+\;8y\;&=&\;4\\7(4)\;+\;8(–3)\;&=&\;4\;\\\;20\;–\;24\;&=&\;4\;\;\\4\;&=&\;4\;\;✔\\&&\end{array}\)          \(\begin{array}{rcl}3x\;–\;5y\;&=&\;27\\3(4)\;–\;5(–3)\;&=&\;27\\12\;+\;15\;&=&\;2\\27\;&=&\;27\;✔\\&&\end{array}\)         

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.5.3: Finding Solutions to Unordered Sets of Equivalent Systems
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give you some slips of paper with systems of equations written on them. Each system represents a step in solving this system:

\( \begin {cases}\frac45 x + 6y = 15\\ \text-x + 18y = 11 \end{cases} \)

Arrange the slips in the order that would lead to a solution. Be prepared to:

1. Describe what move takes one system to the next system.
2. Explain why each system is equivalent to the one before it.


Enter your answers here:

 

\( \begin {cases}\frac45 x + 6y = 15\\ \text-x + 18y = 11 \end{cases} \)

Step 1:

\( \begin {cases} \begin{align}4x + 30y = 75\\ \text-x + 18y = 11 \end{align} \end{cases} \)

Step 2:

\( \begin {cases} \begin{align}4x + 30y = 75\\ \text-4x + 72y = 44 \end{align} \end{cases} \)

Step 3:

\( \begin {cases} \begin{align}4x + 30y &= \hspace{2mm}75\\ 102y &=119 \end{align} \end{cases} \)

Step 4:

\( \begin {cases} \begin{align}4x + 30y &=75\\ y &=\frac76 \end{align} \end{cases} \)

Step 5:

\( \begin {cases} \begin{align}4x +35 &=75\\ y &=\frac76 \end{align}\end{cases} \)

Step 6:

\( \begin {cases} \begin{align}4x &=40\\ y &=\frac76\end{align} \end{cases} \)

Step 7:

\( \begin {cases} \begin{align}x &=10\\ y &=\frac76\end{align} \end{cases} \)

2. Sample Response

  • From the original system to Step 1: Multiply the first equation by 5.
  • From Step 1 to Step 2: Multiply the second equation by 4.
  • From Step 2 to Step 3: Add the two equations in Step 2.
  • From Step 3 to Step 4: Divide each side of \( 102y=119 \) by 102 to solve for \( y \).
  • From Step 4 to Step 5: Substitute \( \frac{7}{6} \)  for y in the first equation and evaluating the expression.
  • From Step 5 to Step 6: Subtract 35 from each side of the first equation.
  • From Step 6 to Step 7: Divide each side of \( 4x = 40 \) by 4 to solve for \( x \).

Extending Your Thinking

This system of equations has the solution \( (5,\text-2) \): \( \begin {cases}Ax - By = 24\\ Bx + Ay = 31 \end{cases} \)

Find the missing values \( A \) and \( B \).

Enter your answers here:

Check your answers:

\( A = 2 \),\( B = 7 \)

page.title: 2.5.4: Building Equivalent Systems
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Here is a system of equations:

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 12a + 5b = -15\\ 8a + b = 11\end{array}\right. \)

1. To solve this system, Diego wrote these equivalent systems for his first two steps.

Step 1

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 12a + 5b = -15\\ -40a + -5b = -55\end{array}\right. \)

Step 2

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 12a + 5b = -15\\ -28a = -70\end{array}\right. \)

Describe the move that Diego made to get each equivalent system. Be prepared to explain how you know the systems in Step 1 and Step 2 have the same solution as the original system.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample response:

Step 1: Multiply the second equation by -5. Multiplying each side of an equation by the same number gives an equivalent equation with the same solution.

Step 2: Add the resulting equation to the first equation to eliminate the variable b. Adding an equal amount to each side of an equation keeps the two sides equal, so the solution for the first equation is also a solution for the sum.

 

2. Write another set of equivalent systems (different than Diego's first two steps) that will allow one variable to be eliminated and enable you to solve the original system. Be prepared to describe the moves you make to create each new system and to explain why each one has the same solution as the original system.

Enter your answer here:

2. Multiply the second equation by \( \frac{3}{2} \) and then subtract the resulting equation from the first equation to eliminate the variable \( a \).

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 12a + 5b = -15\\ 12a + \frac{3}{4}b = \frac{33}{2}\end{array}\right. \)

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 12a + 5b = -15\\ \frac{7}{2}b = -\frac{63}{2}\end{array}\right. \)

Multiply the first equation by -4 and the second equation by 6, and then add the two resulting equations to eliminate the variable \( a \).

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} -14 - 20b = 60\\ 48a + 6b = 66\end{array}\right. \)

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} -14b = 126\\ 48a + 6b = 66\end{array}\right. \)

 

3. Use your equivalent systems to solve the original system. Then, check your solution by substituting the pair of values into the original system.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answers:

\(A=\frac52,\;B=-9\\\)

page.title: 2.5.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Solve the system of equations using elimination.  

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}7x\;–\;2y\;=\;3\\4x\;+\;5y\;=\;3.25\end{array}\right.\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair makes does not make either equation true. You can multiply the first equation by 5 and the second equation by 2.  The answer is \(\left(\frac12,\;\frac14\right)\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair makes the first equation true, but not the second equation true. You can multiply the first equation by 5 and the second equation by 2. The answer is \(\left(\frac12,\;\frac14\right)\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This ordered pair makes the first equations true, but not the second. You can multiply the first equation by 5 and the second equation by 2. The answer is (\(\left(\frac12,\;\frac14\right)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The ordered pair makes both equations true.

page.title: 2.5.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving a System of Equations by Elimination Involving Fractions

You just ordered the steps for solving a system of equations using elimination. Try using these steps when the system has equations containing fractions.

When the system of equations contains fractions, we will first clear the fractions by multiplying each equation by the least common denominator (LCD) of all the fractions in the equation.


Solve the system by elimination: \(\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+\frac12y=6\\\frac32x+\frac23y=\frac{17}2\end{array}\right.\\\)

Solution:

In this example, both equations have fractions. Our first step will be to multiply each equation by the LCD of all the fractions in the equation to clear the fractions.

 

To clear the fractions, multiply each
equation by its LCD.

Simplify.

Now we are ready to eliminate one
of the variables. Notice that both equations are in
standard form.

 

We can eliminate y by multiplying the top equation by −4.

Simplify and add.

Substitute \(x=3\) into one of the original equations.

Solve for y.



Write the solution as an ordered pair.

The ordered pair is \(( 3 , 6 )\) 

Check that the ordered pair is a solution to
both original equations.

 

 

The solution is \(( 3 , 6 )\) .

Try It: Solving a System of Equations by Elimination Involving Fractions

Solve the following system of equations.

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac13\;x\;-\;\frac12y\;=\;1\\\frac34x\;\;-\;y\;=\;\frac52\end{array}\right.\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve this system of equations by elimination:

Write both equations in standard form. If any coefficients are fractions, clear them.

\(\frac13x-\frac12y=1\\\frac34x-y=\frac52\)

To clear the fractions, multiply each equation by its LCD.

\({\style{color:red}6}(\frac13x-\frac12y) ={\style{color:red}6}(1)\\{\style{color:red}4}(\frac34x-y)={\style{color:red}4}(\frac52)\)

Simplify.

\(2 x − 3 y = 6\)
\(3 x − 4 y = 10\)

To get equivalent coefficients of x, we will need to multiply the first equation by 3 and the second equation by 2.

\({\style{color:red}3} (2 x – 3 y ) = {\style{color:red}3} ( 6 ) \)
\({\style{color:red}2} (3 x – 4 y ) = {\style{color:red}2} ( 10 )\)

Simplify.

\(6 x – 9 y = 18\)
\(6 x – 8 y = 20\)

Subtract the equations to eliminate one variable.

 \(\begin{array}{r}6x\;–\;9y\;=\;18\\6x\;–\;8y\;=\;20\\\overline{-y\;=\;-2}\end{array}\)

Solve for the remaining variable.

\(– y = – 2\)
\( y = 2\)

Substitute the solution into any of the equations. Then solve for the other variable.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}2\;x\;–\;3\;y\;&=&\;6\\2\;x\;–\;3\;{\style{color:red}(}\;{\style{color:red}2}\;{\style{color:red})}\;&=&\;6\\2\;x\;–\;6\;&=&\;6\\2\;x\;&=&\;12\\x\;&=&\;6\\&&\end{array}\)

Write the solution as an ordered pair.

\(( 6 , 2 )\)

Check that the ordered pair is a solution to both original equations.

\begin{array}{rcl}\;\;\frac13x\;–\;\frac12y\;&=&\;1\\\frac13{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}6}{\style{color:red})}\;–\;\frac12{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red})}\;&=&\;1\\2\;–\;1\;&=&\;1\\1\;&=&\;1{\style{color:red}✔}\;\\&&\end{array}

\begin{array}{rcl}\;\;\frac34x\;–\;y\;&=&\;\frac52\\\frac34{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}6}{\style{color:red})}\;–\;{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red})}\;&=&\;\frac52\\\frac{18}4\;–\;2\;&=&\;\frac52\\\frac52\;&=&\;\frac52{\style{color:red}✔}\;\\&&\end{array}

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.5.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Solve each system of equations to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson. Enter your answer as “(x,y)” in the space provided. If any coordinate is a non-integer, enter it in decimal format.

1. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} –2x + 5y = –42\\ 7x + 2y = 30 \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (6,−6)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is (6,−6). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 6x – 5y = –34\\ 2x + 6y = 4 \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (−4,2)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is (−4,2). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 5x – y = –2.6\\ −4x − 6y = 1.4 \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (−0.5,0.1)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is (−0.5,0.1). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 7x – 2y = 3\\ 4x + 5y = 3.25 \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (0.5,0.25)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is (0.5,0.25). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 5x + 9y = 16\\ 5x + 9y = 16 \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (−4,4)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is (−4,4). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} \frac{5}{6}x + \frac{1}{4}y = 0\\ \frac{1}{8}x- \frac{1}{2} = -\frac{43}{120} \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (−2,−1)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is (−2,−1). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} \frac{1}{3}x + \frac{1}{9}y = \frac{2}{9}\\ \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{4}{5}y = -\frac{1}{3} \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (6,0)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is (6,0). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 6x – 8y = –0.6\\ 3x + 2y = 0.9 \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (0.8,0.2)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is (0.8,0.2). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 5x – 2y = 2.25\\ 7x – 4y = 3 \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (0.5,0.25)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is (0.5,0.25). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{1}{3}y = \frac{1}{3}\\ \frac{1}{3}x + \frac{1}{4}y = -\frac{1}{8} \end{array}\right. \)

Correct! (9,–12.5)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is (9,–12.5). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.5.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:
  • Explain how multiplying equations by a factor can help us solve systems of linear equations.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.5.1: Multiplying Equations by a Number
    • In this activity, you use technology to graph a system of equations. Then you created new equations by multiplying any of the original equations by the same number. After graphing these new equations, you learned that multiplying an entire equation by a number does not change its solution.
  • 2.5.2: Writing a New System to Solve a Given System
    • In this activity, you reviewed the process of multiplying one equation in a system of equations by a single number to form a new system of equations in order to solve by elimination. By solving the new system of equations, you showed that the solution to the system of equations was not changed from the original system of equations.
  • 2.5.2: Self Check
  • 2.5.3: Finding Solutions to Unordered Sets of Equivalent Systems
    • In this activity, you used your knowledge of solving systems of equations to correctly order the steps used when solving a system by elimination when multiplication is needed in both original equations.
  • 2.5.3: Self Check
  • 2.5.4: Building Equivalent Systems
    • In this activity, you showed that there are multiple ways to solve a system of equations using elimination. Since any one of the original equations can be multiplied by any number without changing the validity of the equation, there are many ways to cancel out a variable when combining the equations in the system.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.5.5: Practice


Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
